data.text: Contents

Government policy places a strong emphasis on the need to share information about service users between health care organisations, professional bodies and commercial third parties, in order to provide the effective provision of seamless care. It is also important that service users trust service providers to respect their privacy and keep their information confidential.

The public services involved in the provision of health and social care have a legal responsibility to ensure that their user of personal information is lawful, properly controlled and that an individual's autonomy is respected. It is important to achieve a striking balance between the need to share information to provide quality care and protecting confidentiality.

The principle underlying this protocol is that personal information must be shared within and between organisations so that people get the care and services that they need. The law should be seen as a framework that enables information to be shared responsibly and safely, protecting both the service user and the service provider from any harm that might arise from unauthorised disclosure and misuse. (see Appendix B – Legal Context).

In July 2016, the Care Quality Commission published ‘Safe data, safe care: Report into how data is safely and securely managed in the NHS', a thematic review of patient data security conducted within the NHS. Within this report, the CQC highlights “What Good Looks Like” in respect of Data Sharing:
Data is shared quickly, effectively and safely with all those involved in the care of patients, including staff in different organisations;
Staff understand the importance of sharing data and are assured that they can do so safely and securely;
NHS organisations are supported to work together to agree common arrangements for data sharing.

This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, agency staff and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.
The purpose of this Protocol is to describe the over-arching framework for sharing information between health, social care and other partner organisations of the Trust.
The principles of the Protocol must be followed by all Information Sharing Partners when sharing personal-identifiable information for purposes specified in Section 8.
This Protocol will be used in conjunction with local Information Sharing Agreements (ISA) that exist between each Information Sharing Partner.
This protocol applies to all information which is owned, held and used by the Trust and/or third parties employed by the Trust.

This Protocol does not give individuals working for Information Sharing Partners licence for unrestricted access to person-identifiable information. It lays down the parameters for the safe and secure sharing of such information in accordance to the privacy laws and only for legitimate purpose documented in each individual ISA.

All Information Sharing Partners are responsible for ensuring that technical and organisational measures are in place to protect the security and integrity of person identifiable information and that their staff are properly trained to understand their responsibilities and comply with the law.
A Glossary of Terms is set out in Appendix B.
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1 Risk and Compliance Group

The purpose of the Risk and Compliance Group is to provide assurance to the Site Leadership Teams / Directors Forum on behalf of the Trust Board of Directors in relation to the implementation of the agreed Risk Management Strategy and internal compliance framework

4.1.2 Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group – is responsible for the review and approval of the information governance and cyber security framework and regulations, including the Information Governance Strategy and Cyber Security Strategy, overseeing the monitoring of the information governance and cyber security framework, ensuring compliance with the Data Security and Protection Toolkit requirements and providing assurance of such for the Trust.
4.1.3 Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 The Chief Executive as the Trust's Accountable Officer has ultimate responsibility for compliance with legal requirements and achievement of standards of best practice and will ensure:
Appropriate delegation of risk management and confidentiality management functions to a Director or equivalent;
Adequate resources to support effective information governance;
Submission of the annual Information Governance Toolkit compliance self- assessment
4.2.2 Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Trust's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.3 Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Site Director is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PID processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PID.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of personal identifiable data where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's
overall governance framework.
4.2.4 Director of Human Resources - has responsibility for ensuring:
That all staff contracts include appropriate clauses to maintain confidentiality.
That the Trust's training programme (induction and statutory) includes the appropriate information governance training and that all staff undergo this training.
There are robust leavers' procedures in place to enable the removal of system access rights in a timely manner.
Disciplinary procedures are conducted, which may be invoked should breaches in information security arise
4.2.5 Head of Information Governance(Supported by Site Information Governance Managers):
Operational responsibility for development and updating of IG management frameworks and Policies in line with local and National requirements.
Providing advice and guidance to support the appropriate use of information sharing.
Supporting the Caldicott Guardian and Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO).
Supporting staff in obtaining Caldicott approval for information sharing.
Aims and Objectives
The aims and objectives of this Protocol are:

To provide an overarching framework to establish and regulate working practice and to provide guidance to enable the secure and confidential transfer of personal-identifiable information shared by information sharing partners party to this Protocol for justifiable and lawful purposes.
To provide guidance and explain the security and confidentiality laws and principles which underpin the use and exchange of personal-identifiable information.
To define the common purposes for holding and sharing personal information.
To protect the privacy and confidentiality of service users.
To ensure information sharing partners minimise any risk of a breach of
confidentiality.
The Legal Framework
5.2.1 The principal legislation concerning the protection and use of personal data is listed below and further explanation in Appendix B:
The Human Rights Act 1998 (article 8)
The Freedom of Information Act 2000
GDPR/UK Data Protection legislation
The Common Law Duty of Confidence

5.2.2 Other legislation may be relevant when sharing specific information. For example, the sharing of information relating to children may involve (but not limited to) consideration of any of the following:
The Children Act 1989 & 2004
Education Act 1996 &
Learning & Skills Act 2000
Education (SEN) Regulations 2001
Children (Leaving Care) Act 2000
Protection of Children Act 1999
Immigration & Asylum Act 1999
Local Government Act 2000
Criminal Justice Act 2002
Crime and Disorder Act 1998
National Health Service Act 1977
Health Act 1999
The Adoption and Children Act 2002
The Health and Social Care Act 2008
Health and Social Care Act 2015
Data covered by this Protocol

5.3.1 Data covered by this Protocol refers to all personal data/Special Categories of Personal Data (previously Sensitive Personal Data) as defined in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) / UK Data protection legislation and by the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (Section 68).
5.3.2 Personal Data

The term ‘personal data' refers to any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject'); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person. This can be held as either manual or electronic records or records held by means of audio and/or visual technology.
5.3.3 Anonymised Data

Partners must ensure anonymised data is not capable of being matched especially when combined with any additional information that could lead to the identity of individual, either directly or by summation.
5.3.4 Pseudonymised Data

Pseudonymisation means the processing of personal data in such a manner that the personal data can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of additional information, provided that such additional information is kept separately and is subject to technical and organisational measures to ensure that the personal data are not attributed to an identified or identifiable natural person;
Further details of the legal context and definitions outlined above can be located in Appendix A & B.
Purposes for Sharing Information
Information sharing partners may use personal-identifiable information for
different purposes with the main primarily being for:
managing the care and treatment of service users
assuring and improving the quality of care and treatment
prevention and detection of serious crime
safeguarding children and vulnerable adults
risk management
investigating complaints
managing & planning services
commissioning and contracting services
research and development

5.4.1 Certain purposes may require consent of the individual service user before their personal data can be used. In some cases additional conditions will also need to be met, e.g. any research must have Research Ethics approval before personal data may be accessed, collected and used for research.
5.4.2 Information must only be shared for a specific lawful purpose, basis or where appropriate consent has be obtained.
5.4.3 Staff should only have access to personal information on a justifiable need to know basis, in order for them to perform their duties in connection with the services they are there to deliver.

5.4.4 Having this agreement in place does not give license for unrestricted access to information another partner organisation may hold. It lays the parameters for the safe and secure sharing of information for a justifiable need to know purpose.
5.4.5 Every member of staff has an obligation to protect confidentiality and is responsible for ensuring that information is only disclosed to those who have a right to see it.

5.4.6 All staff must be trained and be fully aware of their responsibilities to maintain the security and confidentiality of personal information. Staff contracts should also contain a clause on confidentiality which all employees are bound by.
5.4.7 All staff must should follow the procedures and standards that have been agreed and incorporated within this Protocol and any associated ISA.
5.4.8 Each partner organisation will operate lawfully in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) / UK Data protection legislation and its principles at all times.
5.4.9 Clinical/Social Care staff are also bound by their appropriate professional codes of conduct.
Restrictions on use of Information Shared

5.5.1 Information must only be used for the purpose(s) specified at the time of disclosure(s) as defined in the relevant ISA. It is a condition of access that it must not be used for any other purpose without the permission of the Data Controller who supplied the data, unless an exemption applies within the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) / UK Data protection legislation or the information is required to be provided under the terms of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 or any other statutory obligation.

5.5.2 Additional statutory restrictions apply to the disclosure of certain information for example: Criminal Records, HIV and AIDS, Assisted Conception and Abortion, Child Protection. Information about these will be included in the relevant organisational specific ISA.
Consent

5.6.1 Consent of the data subject means any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.

5.6.2 Consent is not the only means by which data can be disclosed. Under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) / UK Data protection legislation, in order to disclose personal information, at least one condition in Article 6 of the GDPR must be met. In order to disclose special category information at least one condition in both Articles 6 and 9 of the GDPR, must be met. Further advice and guidance relating to GDPR conditions can be obtained from the Head of Information Governance or Site Information Governance Manager.

5.6.3 Where a partner organisation has a statutory obligation to disclose personal information then the consent of the data subject is not required; the data subject should be informed that such an obligation exists. However common law duties of confidentiality may still exist or prohibit this disclosure.

5.6.4 If a partner organisation decides not to disclose some or all of the personal information, the requesting authority must be informed. For example the partner organisation may be relying on an exemption or on the inability to obtain consent from the data subject.

5.6.5 Consent has to be signified by some indication on the part of the data subject to the data controller organisation. It is the provider organisations responsibility therefore to ensure that the necessary consent to share criteria has been satisfied as implied consent can often not be relied upon. When using sensitive data, explicit consent must be obtained subject to any existing exemptions. In such cases the Data Subject's consent must be clear and cover items such as the specific details of processing; the data to be processed and the purpose for processing.
5.6.6 If consent is used as a form of justification for disclosure, the data subject must have the right to withdraw consent at any time.

5.6.7 Specific procedures will apply where the data subject is either under the age of 16, or where the data subject does not have the capacity to give informed consent. In these circumstances the relevant policy of the partner organisation should be referred to. Consideration should also be given to other case law, such as the Fraser Guidelines and the requirements of the Mental Capacity Act 2005.
Specific Requirements
5.7.1 There should be a nominated senior professional within each agency covered by this policy.

5.7.2 Patient-identifiable information should be accessed by and transferred freely between the organisations that have agreed and are complying with the policy, for the purposes defined in the Information Sharing Agreement. However, in line with the Caldicott requirements, data must only be patient- identifiable when absolutely necessary.
5.7.3 Patient-identifiable, sensitive or confidential information that leaves the logical boundary of the Trust's managed network must be encrypted in transport i.e Transport Layered Security (TLS)

5.7.4 Careful consideration should be given as to whether personal information is transferred by e-mail. Where e-mail is used to transfer personal information, adequate precautions must be taken to ensure confidentiality. Such precautions include:

Using NHS.net (NHSmail) where both partner organisations have signed the NHSnet Code of Connection or sent from NHS.net to a valid secure email account as defined by the Department of Health e.g .: *gsi.gov.uk, *gsx.gov.uk, *gcsx.gov.uk, *gse.gov.uk, *hscic.gov.uk, *pnn.gov.uk, *scn.gov.uk, *pnn.police.uk, *eu-admin.net, *gsisup.co.uk, *cjsm.net, *psops.net
Encrypting personal-identifiable attachments when e-mailing externally to non-secure domains, in line with the NHS Digital ‘Encryption Guide for NHSmail' (V8)
Sensitive information that would normally be delivered by post should not be sent via e-mail.
5.7.5 Where the partner organisations share access to a single system then:
Access must be on a need-to-know basis; and
Access must be provided only through an authorised secure network.
5.7.6 Where the information is shared amongst the healthcare systems of partner organisations, then:

The patient identifier should be the NHS Number wherever possible; Transmission or delivery of patient-identifiable, sensitive or confidential information must be carried out in a secure manner to protect confidentiality and integrity of the data.

5.7.7 Specific consent will be required from the disclosing organisation's Caldicott Guardian prior to patient-identifiable information being transferred for purposes other than those defined in this document. Caldicott Guardians must ensure that disclosures of patient-identifiable information are consistent with their organisation's registration under the Data Protection Act 2018.
5.7.8 All patient identifiable, sensitive or confidential information must be stored at rest in a secure and restricted manner that is not accessible by unauthorised parties.
Process
5.8.1  Requests
5.8.1.1Only written requests for information will be accepted from external agencies/

health care partners; frequent information sharing is covered by information sharing agreements. These should be provided on headed paper with the legal/justifiable reasons/purposes for the request. For isolated requests to share information externally, the requestor should complete a Data Securtiy Confidentiality Undertaking (DSCU) form (available from the IG Team). The decision to release information will be made by the Caldicott Guardian following review of a completed Information Sharing Agreement/DSCU form by the Head of Information Governance/Site Information Governance Managers. The Information Sharing Agreement template can be obatained from the Information Governance team.

5.8.1.2 Verbal requests for information will be advised to request the information in writing, unless the request is from a nominated person within the Trust, and the information requested is for internal uses only, or where the sharing of information is covered by existing service level agreements.
5.8.1.3 Where there is doubt as to the legitimacy of the request, the person receiving the request should, in the first instance, seek advice from their immediate line manager.

5.8.1.4 If the request for data is legitimate, then the specific information required should be compiled and the appropriate documentation for transfer of patient records completed (See Transfer of Information).
Transfer of Information

5.9.1 It is important for staff to ensure that once information has been compiled, that the person requesting the information is contacted and arrangements made for the appropriate secure method to transfer the information used.
5.9.2 All Information Transfers must be notified to the Head of Information Governance/Site Information Governance Managers with the appropriate Trust procedures being followed.
Care Quality Commission Oversight

CQC, as outlined in Safe Data, Safe Care (2016), have powers to inspect the Trust's IG as part of its inspection round. To this end the Trust must ensure that robust IG practices are in place. CQC specifically requires that Medical Records are accurate, fit for purpose, held securely and held confidential.
Trust Staff
An awareness of this policy will be given at Corporate Trust Induction.

Departmental managers must ensure that new staff attend Induction Training and understand their responsibilities under Information Governance. All staff must complete mandatory Information Governance Training. This training must be completed on an annual basis. Failure to properly inform an employee of their responsibilities could leave the Trust in a vulnerable position.
Partner Organisation Staff
Partner organisations signing up to this protocol must ensure that staff sharing personal identifiable information must have undertaken an appropriate level of Information Governance Training.

This document will be monitored and reviewed regularly by the Caldicott Guardian and/or Head of Information Governance/Site Information Governance Managers. Data relating to concerns raised under the policy will be centrally recorded and reports will be made to the Information Governance Committee on a quarterly basis.

There will be an ongoing program of reviewing Information Sharing Agreements (ISA) by the Head of Information Governance/Site Information Governance Managers in conjunction with the department where the ISA originated and reported to the Information Governance Committee. A database of Information Sharing Agreements will be maintained at site level and reviewed either at one month prior to expiry, or annually (whichever is sooner).

Legislation and applicable regulations that apply to this protocol are listed in Section 5.2 of this document, and Appendix B. However, due to continual changes in legislation, these lists are not exhaustive.

Department of Health (2006) Memorandum of Understanding

data.text: Date of assessment:  09/05/2018
Names of Assessor (s) Matt Barker, Head of Information Governance MSE
Appendix A – Legal Context
General Data Protection Regulation(GDPR)

Data Protection legislation governs the standards for the processing of personal data including the collection, use and disclosure of such information. The legislation requires that Data Controllers meet certain obligations. It also gives individuals or ‘Data Subjects' certain rights with regard to their own personal data. The main standard for processing personal data is compliance with the eight data protection principles summarised as follows:
All personal data will be obtained and processed fairy and lawfully.
Personal data will be held only for the purposes specified.
Only personal data will be held which are adequate, relevant and not excessive in relation to the purpose for which the data is held.
Personal data is accurate and where necessary, kept up to date.
Personal data will be held for no longer than is necessary.
Personal data will be processed in accordance with the Rights of the Data Subject.

Appropriate technical and organisational measures shall be taken against unauthorised or unlawful processing for personal data and against accidental loss or destruction of, or damage to, personal data.
Personal data shall not be transferred to countries outside the European Economic
area except in limited circumstances.

Even in the event that the prevention and detection of crime exemption (Section 29 Data Protection Act) is being relied upon, or other power such as S.115 Crime and Disorder Act, Schedules 2 and 3 conditions must still be satisfied.

Although the aforementioned conditions are likely to apply to any or all of the variable circumstances, it is likely that for the purposes of this Information Sharing Agreement one of the additional conditions specified in secondary legislation, for example: S.I No 417 The Data Protection (Processing of Sensitive Personal Data) Order 2000 and (Daft) The Data Protection (Processing of Sensitive Personal Data) Order 2006, may apply.
S.I 417 Data Protection (Processing of Sensitive Personal Data) Order 2000

The Order lists additional circumstances in which sensitive personal data may be processed. For example, it covers processing for purposes of the prevention or detection of any unlawful act, where seeking the consent of the data subject would prejudice those purposes. It also covers processing required to discharge functions involving the provision of services such as confidential counselling and advice where the subject's consent has not been obtained. In each of the examples above, processing would have to be ‘in the substantial public interest'. This could mean for example, that processing is necessary to protect public safety or to protect vulnerable people.
Draft S.I Data Protection (Processing of Sensitive Personal Data) Order 2006

The Order specifies that information about a criminal conviction or caution may be processed for the purpose of administering an account relating to the payment card used in the commissioning of one of the listed offences relating to indecent images of children.
THE HUMAN RIGHTS ACT 1998

The UK Human Rights Act  gives further effect in domestic law to Articles of the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR). The Act requires all domestic law to be compatible with the Convention Articles and places a legal obligation on all public authorities to act in a manner compatible with the convention. Should a public authority fail to act in such a manner then legal action can be taken under Section 7 of the Act.
Article 8 of the Act states that:

‘Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life, his home and his correspondence and that there shall be no interference by a public authority with this right except as in accordance with the law'.
It is likely that this exchange of information will be for the purposes of one of the following legitimate aims:
In the interests of nation security
Public Safety
Economic wellbeing of the country
The prevention of crime and disorder
The protection of health and morals
The protection of rights or freedoms of others
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT 2000

Information held by or behalf of a public authority may be disclosed to a party requesting it except where statutory exemption applies. For example, personal data is normally exempt under the Act (but may be disclosable under DPA 1998); as is information provided under a duty of confidence.
LEGAL GOVERNMENT ACT

The main power specific to local authorities is section 2 Local Government Act 2000 – the power of ‘well-being'. This enables local authorities to do ‘anything' to promote social, economic or social well-being in their area provided the act is not specifically forbidden by another statute (including the Data Protection Act) and that in carrying out the Act it gives regard to its own community strategy. For example, all councils are taking measures, including data sharing, to reduce crime in their area in order to promote well-being. In addition s.111 Local Government Act  enables local authorities to do anything conducive or incidental to the discharge of any of its functions, providing it has specific statutory authority to carry out those main functions in the first place. The above are general powers available to local authorities. In addition, authorities are granted statutory powers relating to specific activities and these should be referred to as appropriate in relevant ISA's.
POLICE ACT 1996

The Police Act 1996 gives a Constable certain powers. Section 30(1) gives constables all the powers and privileges of a constable throughout England and Wales and Section 30(5) defines these powers as powers under any enactment whenever passed or made. These powers include the investigation and detection of crime, apprehension and prosecution of offenders, protection of life and property and maintenance of law and order.

Under the Police Reform Act 2002, the Chief Constable can delegate certain powers to police staff. In addition, the Code of Practice on the Management of Police Information 2005 defines the policing purpose as:-
Protecting life and property
Preserving order
Preventing the commission of offences
Bringing offenders to justice
Any duty or responsibility arising from common or statute law.

The policing purpose set out in the Code does not replace or supersede any existing duty or power defined by statute or common law. In addition this does not define every policing activity and does not mean that there is no legal basis for performing such activities. For example, roads policing, public order, counter-terrorism or protection of children or other vulnerable groups while not referred to explicitly are none the less legitimate policing functions.
THE CRIME AND DISORDER ACT 1998

Section 115 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 confers power on any ‘relevant authority' (which are the police, local authority, health authority and probation service or to any other person acting on behalf of such authority) to exchange that information which is ‘necessary' or ‘expedient' to help implement the provisions of the Act which includes contributing to local strategies to reduce crime and disorder.

The parties to this exchange agreement are relevant authorities for the purposes of this legislation.  Section  Crime and Disorder  Act  requires that all Local Authorities consider crime and disorder reduction while exercising their duties. Section 5 and 6 of the Crime and Disorder Act imposes a general duty upon local authorities to formulate and implement a strategy for the reduction of crime and disorder in its area.
COMMON LAW DUTY OF CONFIDENCE
The duty of confidence falls within common law opposed to statutory law and derives from cases considered by the courts. There are generally three categories of exception to the duty of confidence:
Where these is a legal compulsion to disclose
Where there is an overriding duty to the public
Where the individual to whom the information relates consented

Partners should consider which of these conditions are the most relevant ones for the purposes of their ISA. The guidance from the Information Commissioner states that because such decisions to disclose ‘in the public interest' involves the exercise of judgment, it is important that they are taken at an appropriate level and that procedures are developed for taking those decision.
The partners to this Assignment should document within this Agreement how this duty will be maintained, e.g. need to know.
CALDICOTT

Where Health Data is concerned; when sharing information with others, due regard must be given to the Caldicott principles listed below. Ensure that all the conditions are met before sending the data. If unsure then speak to your line manager or the appropriate Caldicott Guardian.
Caldicott Principles:
Justify the purpose before sharing information
Only use patient identifiable data when absolutely necessary
Use the minimum that is required, do not share more data than is necessary, i.e. do not send the whole patient record when only the request relates to a recent event
Access to the data should be on a strict need to know basis
Be aware of your responsibilities in complying with organisational policies relating to confidentiality
Understand the law, if uncertain; speak to your line manager
The duty to share information can be as important as the duty to protect patient information
Where Health Data is concerned Health staff and others working in partnership with them, should be aware of the concept of Safe Haven.
Safe Havens will:
Provide a secure location restricting access to only authorised staff and will be locked outside normal hours.
Be staffed by those individuals with authority to access confidential information and who are under contractual and statutory obligations to maintain confidentiality.

Ensure that no confidential information will be released to parties outside the Trust unless it is deemed appropriate. Health Staff should make reference to the Caldicott Principles listed above and seek advice from the Caldicott Guardian where uncertain.
Ensure that wherever possible the NHS number is present and person identifiable data has been removed.
Appendix B – Glossary of Terms
Accessible Record – Unstructured personal information usually in manual form relating to health, education, social work and housing.
Agent – Acts on behalf of the Data Subject.
Aggregated – Collated information in a tabular format.

Anonymised Information/data – Anonymisation requires all elements of potential identifiers to be removed completely so that it does not identify an individual and it would be impossible to identify the individual to who the information relates to. Anonymised information is not confidential and can be shared with other agencies without constraint. If the Data Controller has information, which allows the Data Subject to be identified, regardless of whether or not they intend to identify the individual is immaterial – in the eyes of the Information Commissioner this is not anonymous data – see Pseudonimised data. The Data Controller must be able to
justify why and how the data is no longer personal.
CCTV – Close circuit television.

Consent – any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her. Consent is one lawful basis for processing, and consent (or explicit consent) can also legitimise use of special category data, restricted processing, automated decision-making or overseas transfers. For the processing of special categories of personal data, the GDPR Article 9 condition requires that the subject gives explicit consent. The GDPR does not give a definition of explicit consent. The ICO suggests explicit consent must be expressly confirmed and recorded in writing, in a very clear and specific statement.
Data Controller – A person or a legal body such as a business or a public authority who jointly or alone determines the purposes for which personal data is processed.
Data Flows – The movement of information internally and externally, both within and between organisations.
Data Processing  – Any operation performed on data. The main examples are collection, retention, deletion, use and disclose.
Data Processor – Operates on behalf of the Data Controller. Not staff.
Data Set – A defined group of information.
Data Subject – An individual who is the subject of personal information.
Disclosure  – The passing of information from the Data Controller to another organisation or individual.
Duty of Confidentiality  – Everyone has a duty under the Common Law to safeguard personal information.
EEA – European Economic Area (EEA) – this consists of the fifteen EU members together with Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.
Fair Processing – To inform the Data Subject how the data is to be processed before processing occurs.
GDPR – General Data Protection Regulation – replaces the Data Protection Act 1998 on 25 May 2018.
Information Sharing Agreement – The Information Sharing Agreement template can be obtained from the Information Governance Team via mse.informationgovernance@nhs.net

Healthcare purposes - These include all activities that directly contribute to the diagnosis, care and treatment of an individual and the audit/assurance of the quality of healthcare provided. They do not include research, teaching, financial audit and other management activities

Health Professional – The Data Protection Act 2018 defines a health professional as: any registered medical practitioner, dentist, optician, pharmaceutical chemist, nurse, midwife or health visitor or osteopath. Any person who is registered as a member of a profession to which the Professions Supplementary to Medicine Act 1960 currently extends to clinical psychologist, child psychotherapist and speech therapist, music therapist employed by health service body and scientist employed by such a body as head of department.
Health Record  – Any information relating to health produced by a health professional.
ISA - Information Sharing Agreement.
HIV - Human Immunodeficiency Virus.

Medical Purposes - This is defined in the Data Protection Act 1998 as preventative medicine, medical diagnosis, medical research, the provision of care and treatment and, the management of healthcare services.
Need to know – To access and supply the minimum amount of information required for the defined purpose.
Personal Identifiable Data – Means data relating to a living individual who can be identified from that data (including opinion and expression of intention).
Processing  – Any operation performed on data. Main examples are collection, retention, use, disclosure and deletion.

Pseudonymised data – Data is anonymised but retains a single key such as a code or reference number (but not a ‘national' unique identifier such as the NHS Number or NI Number), known only to the provider of the information so that when it is shared, the provider is able to link back to the identity of the individual to whom the information relates to, but the recipient of the data cannot. It effectively anonymises the data in the hand of the recipient. The provider however must ensure that their use of that data continues to meet all confidentiality and data protection requirements. See also anonymised data.
Purpose  – The use/reason for which information was originally collected for processing.
Recipient – Anyone who receives personal information for the purpose of specific inquires.
Relevant Filing System – Two levels of structure, (i) filing system structured by some criteria (ii) each file structured so that particular information is readily accessible.

Special Category Data –The special categories specifically include personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.

Serious Crime – There is no absolute definition of ‘serious' crime, but section 116 of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 defines some ‘serious arrest-able offences'. These include: Treason, Murder, Manslaughter, Rape, Kidnapping, Certain sexual offences, Causing an explosion, Certain firearms offences, Taking of hostages, Hijacking, Causing death by reckless driving, Offences under prevention of terrorism legislation (disclosures how covered by the Prevention of Terrorism Act 1989).
Subject Access – the individual's right to obtain a copy of information held about themselves.
Third Party – Any person who is not the Data Subject, the Data Controller the Data Processor (includes Health, Housing, Education, Carers, Voluntary Sector etc. as well as members of the public).
